Dialogue.NPCText:
The music of silver bells drifts through Qasaria's dusk as you approach a woman whose every gesture ripples with practiced grace.
Her Sandswept Gossamer Dress shimmers in candlelight, and a Veil of Whispered Secrets obscures her lower face.
Her gaze, dark and keen, sizes you up with the precision of a jeweler inspecting flawed gold.

“Another curious face in Qasaria’s tide of strangers. I am Senna of the Gilded Dust, dancer for the Council’s fetes… and an ear for whispers most would rather silence.
Will you trade stories for stories, wanderer, or have you come seeking something more dangerous?”

Option.text: Your dancing is legendary, but your secrets more so.
I seek work—and coin, if you offer it.
Who do you really serve, Senna?
Tell me about Qasaria’s council.
Tell me your story, Senna.
I’m just watching. No trouble from me.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Senna’s eyes flash with wry amusement.

“A sharper tongue than most. Secrets are a dancer’s truest audience—each step tells a story, every twirl a lie confessed. The Council’s jewels glitter, but what they fear most is what I might overhear as I spin before them.
Karim al-Emerald taught me to read men’s faces as others read palms. Sometimes I wish I had learned a quieter trade…”
She gestures to the Cloak of Golden Dusk at her shoulders.
“Care to see what a little mischief might earn you?”

Option.text: I will help. What must be done?
I want no part of this intrigue.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Senna leans close, voice little more than a hush.

“Karim al-Emerald’s network is wide, but the council grows suspicious. We need new ears where gold and bribes cannot reach.
I have these…”
She reveals slender Grasp of Silent Intent gloves, palm up, holding three crystalline listening stones that faintly pulse with inner light.

“Plant these in the private chambers of the Council of Jewels. I will show you which doors—each one locked tighter than a miser’s heart. When you return, you will have my gratitude… and Karim’s coin.
But know this: even innocents might be overheard. There are things I’d rather not learn.”

Will you help me shape the fate of Qasaria?”

Option.text: I’ll do it. Give me the listening stones.
Who are the targets?
What if I am caught?
Why do you work for Karim?
This is too dangerous.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She presses the crystals into your hand, fingers lingering just a moment.

“They are attuned to my signal. Place one in the chamber of Rafiq al-Ruby, another in the study of Safiya al-Sapphire, and the last in the arena antechamber of Omar al-Onyx.
Be subtle. The council will not forgive discovery.

Return when the deed is done. If your conscience aches, know that you may choose what you overhear… but choose wisely.”

Option.text: I’ll be careful, Senna.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Three stones, three doors.

Rafiq al-Ruby: His command chamber, heavy with the scent of spiced steel and parchment.
Safiya al-Sapphire: Her study above the Sapphire Bazaar, hidden among ledgers and silk.
Omar al-Onyx: The antechamber to the arena, where gladiators whisper their fears.
Each room is guarded. I can provide a Veil of Obscurement for one—choose wisely.”

Option.text: I understand. I’ll try to do what’s right.
This is not for me.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Senna’s gaze grows distant.

“The Council of Jewels—five princes and princesses, each with a blade for a tongue.
Rafiq al-Ruby: Proud and quick to anger, but not without mercy.
Safiya al-Sapphire: Sees profit in every shadow.
Karim al-Emerald: My master, friend, and sometimes… warden.
Yasmin al-Topaz: Older than the dunes, her magic is a rumor feared even by the brave.
Omar al-Onyx: A brute, but loyal to those who earn it.
They call Qasaria the Jewel of the Sands, but in truth, its heart is glass.”

Option.text: On second thought, what do you need done?
Good evening.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Senna pauses, the music in the plaza dimming as if holding its breath.

“My story? That’s a dangerous thing to trade, stranger. Words are daggers in Qasaria.”

Her voice lowers.
“I was born in the Dust Quarter. My mother sold silk. My father sold illusions. I learned to dance before I could walk—but only so we might eat. Karim found me when I was thirteen, mimicking councilors behind a veil for coins. He taught me how to read people… and how to make them bleed without a blade.”

“But I still dance. Not for coin. For freedom.”
She watches your eyes carefully.

“So… do you really want to know me?”

Option.text: I want to know who you are beneath the veil.
I want to know what made you a spy.
Do you regret working for Karim?
No, it’s none of my business.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Her fingers hover over the edge of her veil. She hesitates.

“Few ask that question. Fewer survive the answers.”
She lifts it slightly, revealing a scar near her lips—thin, old, precise.

“This? A merchant prince tried to kiss me when I was sixteen. I kissed him with a blade. Karim called it ‘potential.’”
Her gaze lingers on you.

“You have kind eyes… or clever lies. Either earns my curiosity. Take this—a favor, not a bribe.”

Option.text: You survived. That is enough.
You did what you had to. I don’t judge.
You chose to become what you hated.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Regret? Some nights I dream of quiet: a garden, laughter, no daggers.”

“But those dreams vanish with the dawn. Karim gave me power when I had none. But power is just another kind of chain.”
Her eyes narrow.
“Perhaps I’ll dance my way out of it someday.”

“Tell me—do you dream of escape too?”

Option.text: Yes. I’ve felt that same pull.
No. I’m where I’m meant to be.
You should run now, before it’s too late.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Then perhaps we are alike.”
Her expression softens—genuinely, for once.

“Everyone here wears a mask. But yours… I like the shape of it.”
She pulls a silvered coin from her sash and flicks it into your palm.
“If ever you need help, flip that under moonlight in the Dust Quarter. Someone will come.”

(You feel something stir in your pack.)

Option.text: Thank you, Senna. I won’t forget this.
Until we meet again.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Her eyes narrow, the warmth vanishing.

“Be careful, stranger. You speak of things you do not understand.”
“I do not need your pity. Nor your judgment.”

A note of sadness flickers through her voice.
“You see a spy. I see a survivor. We all bleed the same.”
She turns away.

Option.text: I didn’t mean offense…
Farewell, Senna.
